TEXT.TEXTVALUE: Arrange all the equipments and reagents required for the experiment on the Lab table. Click on each to know the name or Click Continue to start the animation.
The sample containing tube is taken out from the ice box.
The lid of the centrifuge is opened.
The tube containing sample is then kept into the slot of the centrifuge. A tube containing distilled water is then kept into the opposite slot of the centrifuge for balance.
The centrifuge is then set to 13000rpm for 30minutes at 4 degree Celsius.
The lid of the centrifuge is opened.
The Test sample is then taken out from the centrifuge.
The tube is then kept back on the rack.
A syringe is taken from the lab table.
The syringe is then filled with the Test sample.
The syringe is then filled with the Test sample.
A filter is taken from the lab table.
The filter is then fixed into the syringe containing Test sample.
The sample is then drained into a new 15ml tube.
notext
A forceps is taken from the lab bench.
The dialysing tubing dipped in the Ethanol storage solution is then picked out using the forceps.
The dialysing tubing is then washed with the distilled water.
The clamp is taken from the lab table.
One end of the dialysing tubing is then clamped with the dialysing clamp leaving a one cm gap between the clamped position of the tube and the tip of the tube.
The clamped tubing is then placed on the lab table.
A glass pipette is inserted into the pipette holder.
A sample containing tube is taken from the rack.
The lid of the tube is then opened and 5ml of the sample is taken from the tube.
The tube is then kept back on the rack.
The sample is then transferred to the dialysis tubing using the pipette. The dialysis tubing should not be filled more than half the level.
The excess air is then removed from the tubing by gently squeezing the tube by sliding your fingers all the way up the tube and then the tubing is clamped at the top.
The dialysis tubing is then taken and is immersed into a beaker containing PBS buffer at pH=8.
A stir bar is placed into the beaker using forceps.
The visicooler is shown.
The buffer containing beaker is then placed on a magnetic stirrer inside the visicooler.
The buffer containing beaker is then placed on a magnetic stirrer inside the visicooler.
The stirrer is switched ON and the door of the visicooler is closed. It is kept for 3 hours at 4 degree Celsius.
After 3 hours, the door of the visicooler is opened and the stirrer is switched OFF. The beaker containing the dialysis tubing is taken from the visicooler.
The beaker is then placed on the lab table and the dialysis tubing is taken out from the buffer.
The color of the solution in the dialysis tubing turned clear from a yellowish color.
Dialysis tubing is then placed on an absorbent paper to remove the excess buffer in the end of the tubing outside the clamped area. The tubing is wiped gently with another absorbent paper.
The dialysis tubing is taken and the upper clamp is released.
The dialysis tubing is taken and the upper clamp is released.
The suspension in the tubing is pipette out using a Pasteur pipette.
A sterile 15 ml tube is taken from the rack.
The suspension from the Pasteur pipette is then transferred to the 15 ml tube. The tube is labeled as “Sample”.
The tube labeled “Sample “is then kept in ice.
The bottle containing Double distilled water is taken from the lab bench.

The Double distilled water is then added to the column so as to wash the column; the stop cock of the column is released so that drops of water flow out through the tip. The stop is now closed and the double distilled water is then added again to the column and repeats the same.

A cotton wool is plunged into the column and the cotton is gently pushed to the tip of the column using a glass rod. The column is then filled with Protein A sepharose solution till the marking shown.
The bottle containing PBS solution is taken from the lab bench.

The PBS solution containing bottle is then squeezed and the buffer is gently added to fill the column. The stop cock is then released and the buffer will start to move through the column outlet. The stop cock is then closed.
The sample containing tube is then taken out from the ice.
The lid of the tube is then removed.
The sample is then slowly added to the column.
The sample containing tube is then closed.
The tube is then kept back in the rack.
The bottle containing PBS solution is taken from the lab bench.
The PBS solution containing bottle is then squeezed and the buffer is gently added to fill the column.
The test tube labeled “D” is taken from the rack.
The stop cock of the column is released and the buffer coming out [1ml each] will be collected in the test tube labeled “D”. The stop cock is then closed.
The test tube labeled “D” is then taken and kept back into the test tube rack.
Similarly collect the buffer [1ml each] in test tubes labeled “A”, “B” and “C” also.
A cuvette is taken from the cuvette rack.
The bottle containing Deionized water is then taken from the lab bench.
The deionized water is then transferred into the cuvette.
The lid of the spectrophotometer is opened.
The absorbance is set to 280nm.
The ENTER button is then clicked.
The cuvette containing BLANK solution is kept into the cuvette slot of the spectrophotometer and the lid of the spectrophotometer is then closed.
The BLANK button is then clicked and the absorbance is set to zero.
The lid of the spectrophotometer is now opened and the cuvette containing BLANK solution is now taken out from the slot.
The cuvette is then kept back into the rack.
The test tube labeled “D” is taken from the rack.
Another cuvette is taken from the rack.
The contents of the test tube labeled “D” is then transferred to the cuvette.
The cuvette is then kept into the slot of the spectrophotometer and the lid is closed.
The SAMPLE button is clicked and the absorbance of the test solution is noted.
A glass pipette is inserted into a pipette pump.
A 15ml tube containing 0.1M citric acid at pH=3 is taken from the rack.
The tube is then opened and 3ml of the citric acid is pipetted out using the glass pipette.
The pipetted citric acid is then loaded into the column.
A micropipette is taken from the rack.
The volume is adjusted to 50 microlitre.
A micropipette tip is then inserted.
The cap of the tube containing Tris base buffer is removed and 50 microlitre of the buffer is pipetted out using the micropipette.
A microfuge tube is taken from the rack.
The cap of the microfuge tube is then opened and the buffer is now transferred to the tube from the pipette.
The microfuge tube is then kept back on the rack and another microfuge tube is taken from the rack.
Similarly, the remaining microfuge tubes were filled with the Tris base buffer.
A microfuge tube containing buffer is taken from the rack.
The microfuge tube is then kept under the column to collect the transparent liquid coming out of the column. All the tubes are kept for collecting the liquid coming out from the column outlet.
notext
A forceps is taken from the lab bench.
The dialysing tubing dipped in the Ethanol storage solution is then picked out using the forceps.
The dialysing tubing is then washed with the distilled water.
The clamp is taken from the lab table.
One end of the dialysing tubing is then clamped with the dialysing clamp leaving a one cm gap between the clamped position of the tube and the tip of the tube.
A micropipette is taken from the rack.
A fresh micropipette tip is inserted into the pipette.
The sample from the vial is taken using a pipette.
The sample is then transferred to the dialysis tubing.
The sample from the second vial is taken using a pipette.
The sample is then transferred to the dialysis tubing.
The sample from the vial is taken using a pipette.
The sample is then transferred to the dialysis tubing.
The sample from the last vial is taken using a pipette.
The sample is then transferred to the dialysis tubing.
The excess air is then removed from the tubing by gently squeezing the tube by sliding your fingers all the way up the tube and then the tubing is clamped at the top.
The dialysis tubing is then immersed in a beaker containing PBS buffer at pH=7.3.
Using a forceps, stir bar is placed inside the beaker containing the PBS buffer.
The buffer containing beaker along with the dialysis tubing is taken from the lab bench.
The door of the Visicooler is opened and the beaker is placed in the magnetic stirrer inside the visicooler.
The stirrer is switched ON and the door of the visicooler is closed. It is kept for 3hours at 4 degree Celsius.
After 3 hours, the door of the visicooler is opened and the stirrer is switched OFF. The beaker containing the dialysis tubing is taken from the visicooler.
The beaker is then placed on the lab table and the dialysis tubing is taken out from the buffer.
The beaker is then placed on the lab table and the dialysis tubing is taken out from the buffer.
Dialysis tubing is then placed on an absorbent paper to remove the excess buffer in the end of the tubing outside the clamped area. The tubing is wiped gently with another absorbent paper.
The dialysis tubing is taken and the upper clamp is released.
The dialysis tubing is taken and the upper clamp is released.
The suspension in the tubing is pipetted out using a Pasteur pipette.
A sterile 15 ml tube is taken from the rack.
The suspension from the Pasteur pipette is then transferred to the 15 ml tube.
The tube with the dialysed sample is kept in the refrigerator.
